head.title: Atomic Layer Deposition of Pt Thin Films Using Dimethyl (N,N-Dimethyl-3-Butene-1-Amine-N) Platinum and O2 Reactant | Chemistry of Materials

meta.content: Atomic Layer Deposition of Pt Thin Films Using Dimethyl (N,N-Dimethyl-3-Butene-1-Amine-N) Platinum and O2 Reactant

Pt thin films, using the Pt precursor, dimethyl(N,N-dimethyl-3-butene-1-amine-N)platinum (DDAP, C8H19NPt), were deposited by atomic layer deposition (ALD). The growth characteristics of the Pt thin films were systemically investigated. A saturated growth rate was obtained with an increase in precursor and reactant pulse times, revealing the nature of the ALD self-limiting process. The growth rate increased with increasing deposition temperature and finally became saturated above 280 °C, showing a high growth rate of 0.85 Å/cycle. The short incubation time for Pt nucleation promoted the growth characteristics, which can be favorable for catalytic applications. The high reactivity and small adsorbate size produced the relatively high growth rate of the Pt thin films deposited with the DDAP precursor. A very low resistivity, close to the value of bulk Pt, was obtained for all Pt thin films deposited at various temperatures. The low resistivity was due to the similar crystalline structure and very high purity of the Pt thin films at all deposition temperatures explored in this study. In addition, Pt thin films were also deposited on a high-aspect-ratio substrate and showed good uniformity and step coverage, with a constant work function, which can be promising for electrode applications. Synthesis of Pt films by ALD using the DDAP Pt precursor and O2 is a noteworthy approach for obtaining films with a high growth rate and low resistivity.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

div.p:
Pt thin films, using the Pt precursor, dimethyl(
N
,
N
-dimethyl-3-butene-1-amine-
N
)platinum (DDAP, C
8
H
19
NPt), were deposited by atomic layer deposition (ALD). The growth characteristics of the Pt thin films were systemically investigated. A saturated growth rate was obtained with an increase in precursor and reactant pulse times, revealing the nature of the ALD self-limiting process. The growth rate increased with increasing deposition temperature and finally became saturated above 280 °C, showing a high growth rate of 0.85 Å/cycle. The short incubation time for Pt nucleation promoted the growth characteristics, which can be favorable for catalytic applications. The high reactivity and small adsorbate size produced the relatively high growth rate of the Pt thin films deposited with the DDAP precursor. A very low resistivity, close to the value of bulk Pt, was obtained for all Pt thin films deposited at various temperatures. The low resistivity was due to the similar crystalline structure and very high purity of the Pt thin films at all deposition temperatures explored in this study. In addition, Pt thin films were also deposited on a high-aspect-ratio substrate and showed good uniformity and step coverage, with a constant work function, which can be promising for electrode applications. Synthesis of Pt films by ALD using the DDAP Pt precursor and O
2
is a noteworthy approach for obtaining films with a high growth rate and low resistivity.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Platinum (Pt) thin films are versatile due to their excellent functional properties, such as low resistivity, high work function, ability to catalyze chemical reactions, high thermal stability, corrosion resistance, and oxidation resistance.
(1−3)
Because of these useful characteristics, Pt thin films have been employed for many applications, such as electrodes in dynamic random-access memory structures and ferroelectric random-access memory structures, gate electrodes in field-effect transistors,
(4−7)
various nanosized catalysts in chemical transformation and energy conversion reactions, and environmental protection.
(8−10)
For the aforementioned applications of Pt, atomic layer deposition (ALD) has been regarded as a unique and efficient deposition process to produce the exact thickness with control on the composition, quality, uniformity, and conformality of the films over complex three-dimensional (3D) structures due to its self-limiting chemisorbed reaction.
(11−14)
Additionally, the initial growth control of the metal ALD process makes it possible to precisely produce size-controlled metal nanoparticles with high density.
(15)
Thus, the ALD of Pt thin films has become important due to increasing demands.

Pt thin films prepared by the ALD process have been reported using well-known Pt precursors: MeCpPtMe
3
and Pt(acac)
2
. Aaltonen et al.
(16)
first successfully deposited ALD Pt thin films using MeCpPtMe
3
and oxygen. They found a saturated growth rate (0.48 Å/cycle) and low resistivity (12 μΩ·cm with 110 nm) with low impurity contents (carbon 0.5–1 atom % and oxygen 1–2 atom %) in the film. Hamalainen et al.
(17)
also deposited ALD Pt thin films using the other Pt precursor, Pt(acac)
2
, and O
3
gas. The as-deposited Pt thin film showed a higher growth rate than that with MeCpPtMe
3
(0.7 Å/cycle) but had a relatively high impurity content (carbon 0.5 atom % and oxygen 8.3 atom % at 200 °C). Due to its lower impurity, MeCpPtMe
3
was mainly regarded as an effective precursor due to the absence of better alternatives. The impurity in films obtained using MeCpPtMe
3
originates due to the incorporation of the methylcyclopentadienyl ligands of the precursor, which are very hard to activate or remove from the surface of the films.
(18,19)
On the other hand, ligand moieties such as methyl, diketonates, amidinates, and aminoalkoxides are potentially reactive and create a new decomposition channel.
(20)

Generally, noble metals by the ALD process suffer from poor nucleation due to the difference in surface energy between the substrate and metals, which can influence the growth characteristics.
(21−24)
Additionally, the composition and electrical properties of noble metal thin films can be modified by using other counter reactants and gas-phase electron activation.
(25−27)
Therefore, by using the above Pt precursors, the effects of various deposition parameters, such as pretreatment and different reactants, such as O
3
generated from ozone generators and plasmas, have been studied to improve the growth behavior and functional properties of Pt thin films,
(2,28−31)
which is highly desired to improve the performance in microelectronic devices and catalysis. Thus, the development of ALD Pt films with improved electrical and growth characteristics without additional treatments is still a challenge. One of the efficient strategies is to deposit films using alternative precursors containing highly reactive and easily removable ligands.

In this study, for the first time, an alternative precursor, dimethyl((3,4-η)
N
,
N
-dimethyl-3-butene-1-amine-
N
)platinum (DDAP, C
8
H
19
N
Pt), and oxygen (O
2
) were used to deposit ALD Pt thin films that possess a high growth rate and low resistivity without any detectable defects or impurities. The improved growth behavior of the Pt films was demonstrated by investigating the initial stage of rapid nucleation and steric hindrance behavior. The high film crystallinity and high purity of the thin films resulted in a low resistivity at all investigated substrate temperatures. The Pt thin films were also deposited on a 3D structured substrate with a high aspect ratio to investigate the deposition uniformity of the ALD process using the DDAP precursor, and the work function of the Pt thin films with a low thickness on SiO
2
was investigated.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Pt thin films were deposited on 5 in. SiO
2
(250 nm)/Si(100) substrates using a 6 in. shower head type ALD system as a function of the substrate temperature from 190 to 340 °C with DDAP (Tanaka Kikinzoku Kogyo K. K., over 99% purity) as the Pt precursor (
Figure
1
). The Pt precursor was contained in a bubbler-type stainless-steel canister and heated to 60 °C to provide sufficient vapor pressure (0.041 Torr). The precursor vapor was then supplied to the substrate by Ar gas at a flow rate of 100 sccm. The feeding line was heated to 100 °C to avoid condensation of the Pt precursor. One cycle of Pt thin films consisted of a Pt precursor pulse with Ar carrier gas for 10 s, a purge pulse with Ar carrier gas for 10 s, an O
2
reactant pulse for 5 s, and another purge pulse for 10 s. Before deposition, the SiO
2
substrate was dipped in acetone and isopropyl alcohol sequentially, rinsed with deionized (DI) water, and then dried with N
2
gas. O
2
gas (99.999%) was used as an oxidant at a flow rate of 50 sccm. This cycle was repeated to obtain approximately 30 nm Pt thin films. During the process, Ar gas was continuously supplied to the chamber at a flow rate of 200 sccm, and the chamber working pressure was maintained at 1 Torr.

div.p: Figure 1. Molecular two-dimensional structure of the DDAP precursor.

div.div:
To investigate the adsorption energy of DDAP, a van der Waals corrected density functional theory (DFT) calculation was performed, which was implemented in the Vienna Ab initio simulation package code.
(32)
The projector-augmented wave potential and Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof approximation were used for the ionic and exchange and correlation potentials with a cutoff energy of 550 eV.
(33−35)
The dispersion energy was expressed by a density-dependent dispersion correction scheme.
(36,37)
The positions of all atoms were optimized within a conjugate-gradient algorithm. The Hellman–Feynman forces were less than 0.01 eV/Å. A simple cubic unit cell with a lattice constant of 20 Å was used to prevent the interaction between the Pt precursors. A 3 × 3 × 3
k
-mesh was generated for all calculations. To reduce the calculation time, a Si(OH)
4
cluster was used, instead of the hydroxylated silica surface.

The resistivity of the Pt thin films was calculated using the sheet resistance measured by a four-point probe (Advanced Instrument Technology, CMT-SR2000N) and film thickness. The film thickness and microstructure were investigated by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, Hitachi, S-4800). X-ray reflectivity (XRR, Philips, X’pert PRO-MRD) was used to check the low thickness of the Pt thin films with a Cu Kα source (1.54 Å), using a voltage of 40 kV and anode current of 25 mA. The crystal structures were identified by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker, D8 Advance) with 2θ mode using 1.54 Å Cu Kα radiation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Electron Corporation, MICROLAB) was performed to check the chemical bonding and composition of the Pt thin films with a spot size of 400 μm, an energy step size of 0.1 eV, and a pass energy of 50 eV. A schematic diagram of the Pt precursor was drawn using 3D Chem draw software. A hole-pattern structure image was obtained by field-emission transmission electron microscopy (FE-TEM, FEI, TALOS F200X), operating at 200 kV. Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM, Asylum Research, MFM-3D) was used to investigate the work function and topography of the thin films. A Ti/Ir-coated silicon tip was used with a spring constant of 2.8 N/m, a resonant frequency of 75 kHz, and a tip radius of 25 nm.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Figure
2
shows the growth characteristics and electrical properties as a function of precursor pulse time, O
2
pulse time, and substrate temperature. A saturated growth rate of approximately 0.85 Å/cycle was achieved when the Pt precursor pulse time exceeded 7 s with a fixed O
2
reactant pulse time of 5 s at a temperature of 280 °C (
Figure
2
a). Additionally, as a function of O
2
pulse time, a saturated growth rate (0.85 Å/cycle) was obtained when the pulse time was longer than 3 s (
Figure
2
b). The above results indicate that one of the most important inherent ALD characteristics, the self-limiting process, was successfully achieved by the chemisorption reaction between the Pt precursor and the O
2
reactant.
(16,38)
No significant change in resistivity was observed with the increase in the Pt precursor pulse time and O
2
pulse time, except for the unsaturated pulse time regions.
Figure
2
c shows the growth rate of Pt thin films with increasing substrate temperature from 190 to 340 °C. No Pt thin films were observed below 190 °C. The growth rate increased from 0.57 to 0.85 Å/cycle when the deposition temperature ranged from 190 to 280 °C, respectively. According to previous studies,
(2,20)
the increased growth rate can be attributed to the enhanced adsorption of the Pt precursor or a change in the reaction mechanism after increasing the temperature. The growth rate was almost comparable from 280 to 340 °C, which was considered to be the “ALD window” governed by the reactivity and stability of the Pt precursor and the surface functional group.
(39)
The self-limiting process was also confirmed at a deposition temperature of 340 °C due to the high thermal stability of DDAP (
Figure S1
). In this region, the growth rate of 0.85–0.86 Å/cycle was higher than those of other reported Pt precursors (MeCpPtMe
3
-O
2
: 0.3–0.5 Å/cycle at 200–300 °C; Pt(acac)
2
-O
3
: 0.5–0.7 Å/cycle at 140–200 °C).
(16,17)
Figure
2
d shows the resistivity variation of Pt thin films as a function of the substrate temperature. The resistivity was almost constant with increasing deposition temperature at a fixed thickness of approximately 30 nm. The resistivity (13.5 μΩ·cm) value was very close to that of bulk Pt (10.6 μΩ·cm),
(28)
revealing a very low defect density and impurity level in the as-deposited Pt thin film, which is discussed later.

div.p:
Figure 2. Change in the growth rate and resistivity of the Pt thin film with (a) precursor pulse times at a fixed O
2
pulse time of 5 s and (b) O
2
pulse times at a fixed Pt precursor pulse time of 10 s at a temperature of 280 °C. Change of (c) growth rate and (d) resistivity with the deposition temperature from 190 to 340 °C.

div.div:
As most of the noble metal thin films prepared by ALD undergo incubation for nucleation growth,
(28,29,31)
the growth and electrical characteristics can be influenced by the growth mechanism during the initial stage of growth with the transition regime, the outmost surface changes from the substrate surface to the final saturated and continuous surface of the metal film.
(40,41)
Therefore, we conducted a careful study to understand the growth mechanism of Pt thin films.
Figure
3
a shows the variation of Pt thin film thickness (determined by FE-SEM) depending on the ALD cycles. With increasing growth cycles, the Pt thin film thickness was found to increase linearly due to the self-limiting reaction of Pt thin films during the ALD process. The extrapolated line fitted to the experimental values goes through a point near the origin without intersecting the
x
-axis and
y
-axis.
(42)
This outcome indicates immediate nucleation of Pt thin films by using the DDAP precursor on the substrate (SiO
2
). Considering the resolution limit of a FE-SEM, XRR was used to check the low thickness of the Pt thin films.
(40)
The fitted XRR results (
Figure
3
b) show that the thicknesses of Pt thin films below 200 cycles as a function of the number of ALD cycles are comparable with the FE-SEM-analyzed thicknesses. However, below 50 cycles, due to the weak XRR oscillations, measurement of thickness values may be imprecise. The extrapolated line from XRR below 20 nm also confirms a very short incubation time. On the other hand, using the well-known MeCpPtMe
3
precursor and O
2
reactant, the extrapolated line passing through the
x
-axis indicates that the Pt thin films possess a long incubation period up to 37 cycles, as shown in
Figure
3
a. Also, a very short nucleation delay of Pt thin films using the DDAP precursor can be reconfirmed from the observation of resistivity with the film thickness. The resistivity of metallic thin films is very sensitive to the continuity of the films. A fast formation of continuous film can result in lower resistivity at the same film thickness, and it can also result in a fast saturation of electrical resistivity at smaller thicknesses, as shown in
Figure
3
c,d. It is notable that the resistivities of Pt thin films using DDAP were lower than those of films using MeCpPtMe
3
at similar film thicknesses (
Figure
3
c). Moreover, the resistivity of Pt thin films using DDAP showed a faster saturation at higher thickness than 12.6 nm (
Figure
3
d), whereas the films using MeCpPtMe
3
exhibited a relatively slower saturation at higher thickness than 21.9 nm (
Figure
3
c). Thus, the measurement of resistivity also supports a very short nucleation delay of Pt thin films using the DDAP precursor.

div.p: Figure 3. Change in the thickness of Pt thin films depending on the number of ALD cycles investigated by (a) FE-SEM analysis and (b) XRR simulation, respectively. Corresponding resistivity of Pt thin films as a function of thickness investigated by (c) FE-SEM analysis and (d) XRR simulation, respectively.

div.div:
To visually identify the rapid nucleation of Pt thin films using DDAP, a planar-view SEM study was conducted with different ALD cycles from 20 to 100 cycles (
Figure
4
). At below 20 cycles, a highly dense Pt film nucleated with an island structure on the SiO
2
substrate, as clearly observed in the SEM images. Upon increasing the number of cycles, the Pt islands increased in size (40 cycles) and finally coalesced to form a continuous thin film above 80 cycles. This continuous Pt film (>80 cycles) provided a stable and detectable low-resistance Pt thin film, as shown in
Figure
3
b. Based on
Figures
3
and
4
, it is concluded that a shorter incubation time at the initial stage offers very faster nucleation, and, as a result, Pt thin films using the DDAP precursor can promote growth and electrical characteristics at short cycles compared with other precursors, including MeCpPtMe
3
, as demonstrated above. Additionally, it is worth mentioning that dense Pt nanoparticles formed by rapid nucleation are also highly advantageous for applications as a catalyst.

div.p:
Figure 4. Planar-view SEM images of Pt thin films on SiO
2
substrates at the initial cycles from 20 to 100 cycles.

div.div:
Generally, the initial growth stage of nucleation and growth rate in the ALD process can be strongly influenced by the size of the adsorbate and the surface reactivity of the precursor. Therefore, the adsorption mechanism of DDAP on the surface of the SiO
2
substrate was investigated using DFT calculations. It was considered that the DDAP precursor reacted with the terminal hydroxyl (−OH) functional groups of the SiO
2
surface, followed by formation and elimination of CH
4
,
(43)
and adsorption of the rest (CH
3
-eliminated precursor). The calculated adsorption energy (−16.6 kcal/mol) of the CH
3
-eliminated fragments of DDAP was more exothermic compared to the reported adsorption energy of other precursors such as MeCpPtMe
3
,
(44)
resulting in a high reactivity of DDAP with fast nucleation and shorter incubation delay. In addition, the size of the CH
3
-eliminated fragments of the DDAP precursor is smaller than that in the case of MeCpPtMe
3
, leading to a lower steric hindrance effect (
Figures S2, S3, and Table S1
).
(45,46)
In addition, the butene amine ligand could be subsequently removed to form a smaller PtMe adsorbate on the SiO
2
substrate by breaking the Pt–N bond of the adsorbed DDAP precursor without any combustion reaction. Since the nucleophilicity of the nitrogen atom in butene amine can be decreased due to the delocalization of its lone pair with the alkene carbon moiety, the butene amine ligand, which can possess a high steric hindrance from the alkene chain during the interaction,
(47)
could lead to a weak interaction with the surface and facilitate simple detachment and desorption at deposition temperatures from 190 to 340 °C. Thus, the DDAP precursor can adsorb on the SiO
2
surface as a smaller adsorbate, compared with MeCpPtMe
3
. And, its smaller adsorbate size can result in lower steric hindrance to block the reaction of the neighboring reactive sites during the deposition, leading to a high growth rate and short nucleation delay time.
(45)
In addition, the Pt thin films synthesized in this work exhibited an extremely high density (∼21.5 g/cm
3
), even close to the value of bulk Pt (21.5 g/cm
3
)
(16)
(
Figure S4 and Table S2
). According to the results discussed above, it can be demonstrated that the small adsorbate size and high reactivity resulting in fast nucleation and shorter incubation delay can probably promote the deposition of dense Pt thin films.

It is also believed that the electrical properties of Pt thin films can be influenced by many factors, such as crystallinity, microstructure, and intrinsic defects. To understand the impact of these factors on the electrical properties of Pt thin films, XRD and XPS analysis were conducted.
Figure
5
shows the XRD spectra of approximately 30 nm-thick Pt thin films deposited at different temperatures. All Pt thin films contained similar crystalline metallic Pt with (111), (200), and (220) orientations, corresponding to the high-resolution TEM results of the Pt film deposited at 190 °C (
Figure S5
). A similar grain size (∼21.53 nm), calculated along the (111) orientation, was found for all samples, which is consistent with the cluster size (19–21 nm) measured from the SEM images (
Figure S6
), resulting in stable and identical electrical properties for all Pt thin films deposited at all deposition temperatures.

div.p: Figure 5. XRD spectra of approximately 30 nm-thick Pt thin films deposited at the respective deposition temperatures.

div.div:
To investigate the chemical binding energy and composition of the Pt thin films, XPS analysis was performed, as shown in
Figure
6
. Pt 4f
7/2
at 72.00 eV and Pt 4f
5/2
at 74.70 eV were detected in the metallic Pt thin films.
(30)
No shifting of the Pt peak was observed, indicating constant binding energies of the Pt core level regardless of the deposition temperatures. The C 1s, O 1s, and N 1s peaks were not detected, revealing very low defects in the Pt thin films in contrast to MeCpPtMe
3
-Pt thin films, which possessed relatively higher impurities (
Figure S7
). These results strongly support the stable and low resistivity of Pt thin films at various temperatures. Highly pure Pt thin films were also confirmed by Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) analysis, corroborating the XPS results (
Figure S8
). For no detectable impurities within Pt thin films, it is considered that atmospheric gases are unable to diffuse into the Pt thin films due to their high film density (
Table S2
). Likewise, although the DDAP precursor contains carbon and nitrogen, and O
2
gas that acted as a reactant during the deposition process, no such elements were detected by both XPS and AES in the Pt thin films. Therefore, it could also be suggested that all byproducts related to carbon and nitrogen were completely removed during the deposition process. On the other hand, other well-known Pt precursors, such as the cyclopentadienyl compound, MeCpPtMe
3
, normally suffer from ligand removal at low temperatures due to their low reactivity toward decomposition.
(16,48,49)
Additionally, oxygen-containing moieties of Pt precursors, such as Pt(acac)
2
, can be hydrogenated to form alcohols and water, which are difficult to be completely purged out.
(50)
Therefore, they can leave undesired impurities within the Pt thin films. However, the DDAP precursor can provide a very pure Pt thin film due to the absence of a Cp ligand and oxygen in the precursor. The high-purity Pt thin films resulted in very low electrical resistivity, analogous to the Pt bulk, and is a promising film for various applications.

div.p: Figure 6. Pt 4f, C 1s, O 1s, and N 1s XPS spectra of Pt thin films at different substrate temperatures.

div.div:
To explore the potential of Pt thin films in IC device manufacturing and porous structures, the step coverage was also tested using high-aspect-ratio hole patterns.
(51,52)
Figure
7
a shows the cross-sectional high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of Pt thin films with a thickness of ∼12 nm deposited on a substrate patterned with SiO
2
holes. The aspect ratio was approximately 25 with a lateral dimension of 60 nm and a depth of 1.5 μm. As shown in
Figure
7
b, the Pt thin film deposited inside the trench showed good uniformity. The conformity along all trench regions and step coverage of the lower region compared to the upper side was calculated to be ∼82%, which is considered to be excellent for metal ALD processes in high-aspect-ratio hole patterns. Additionally,
Figure
7
c shows the topography, contact potential difference (CPD), and work function for a 100-cycle Pt thin film. In the topography data, the CPD has negative values along the yellow line of the long-range film matrix, suggesting a higher work function compared to that of the standard AFM tip (5.27 eV). In the KPFM mode,
(53)
when an oscillation electrostatic force is generated between the AFM tip and the Pt film surface by applying an alternating current voltage to the tip, the direct current voltage compensates for the electrostatic interaction that originates from a CPD. The CPD is defined as
(54)
where Φ
tip
and Φ
sample
are the tip and Pt film work functions, respectively. Here,
q
is the absolute value of the electron charge (−1.6 × 10
–19
C). Thus, the work function of Pt thin films can be calculated from the known work function of the tip. From this equation, a uniform work function value of 5.49 eV for Pt thin films with a low thickness (approximately 8–9 nm) can be successfully obtained with a long-range Pt thin film.
(55)
As shown in
Figures
3
and
4
, dense and rapidly nucleated Pt films using DDAP led to the fast formation of continuous Pt thin films after a small number of cycles, resulting in stable work functions throughout the films. This indicates a promising route toward an efficient ALD process for preparing Pt thin films using the DDAP Pt precursor for various electronic applications.

div.p:
Figure 7. Step coverage of Pt thin films (120 cycles at 280 °C deposition temperature) with a high aspect ratio of ∼25 with lateral dimension and depth of 60 and 1500 nm, respectively, investigated by (a) low- and (b) high-magnification TEM images. (c) Work function analysis using KPFM measurement: KPFM image of the Pt thin film, the plot of CPD values vs Pt thin film distance along the yellow line in the KPFM image, and work function for the Pt thin film distance calculated from CPD. A 100-cycle Pt thin film (less than approximately 8–9 nm according to XRR) deposited at 280 °C on a SiO
2
substrate was used for KPFM.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Pt thin films using the DDAP precursor were successfully deposited by the ALD process. A saturated growth rate (0.85 Å/cycle) for Pt thin films was achieved when the pulse time reached 7 and 3 s for the Pt precursor and O
2
reactant, respectively. Upon increasing the substrate temperature from 190 to 280 °C, the growth rate first increased from 0.57 to 0.85 Å/cycle and then showed a relatively higher growth rate of 0.86 Å/cycle at 340 °C, possibly due to the adsorption of small-sized adsorbates. Little nucleation delay was observed at the initial stage during the deposition process, indicating the enhanced growth characteristics of Pt thin films. A constant resistivity was observed for Pt thin films (approximately 13.5 μΩ·cm, very close to that of bulk Pt) at all deposition temperatures, which can be due to the stable crystallinity and microstructure. No carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen impurities were detected by chemical composition analysis, indicating the formation of highly pure Pt thin films. Very good step coverage of the Pt ALD process was confirmed by cross-sectional analysis of samples from the top surface to the bottom of the high-aspect-ratio substrate. A uniform work function was obtained for Pt films with a small thickness along the long-range surface of the film. Thus, an efficient Pt ALD process using DDAP and O
2
can be potentially utilized to prepare Pt thin films for various electronic and catalytic applications due to their enhanced growth characteristics and highly stable and improved electrical properties, such as enhanced growth rate, fast growth nucleation, low electrical resistance and uniform work function as well as excellent uniformity and very low impurities.

Platinum and platinum oxide films were deposited by remote plasma at. layer deposition (ALD) from the combination of (methylcyclopentadienyl)trimethylplatinum (MeCpPtMe3) precursor and O2 plasma. A short O2 plasma exposure (0.5 s) resulted in low resistivity (15 μΩ/cm), high d. (21 g/cm3), cubic Pt films, whereas a longer O2 plasma exposure (5 s) resulted in semiconductive PtO2 films. Plasma-assisted at. layer deposition (ALD) processes were developed for the deposition of platinum films at room temp. High-quality, virtually pure films with a resistivity of 18-24 μΩ cm were obtained for processes consisting of MeCpPtMe3 dosing, O2 plasma exposure, and H2 gas or H2 plasma exposure. The H2 pulses were used to reduce the PtOx that is otherwise deposited at low substrate temps. It is shown that the processes enable the deposition of Pt on polymer, textile, and paper substrates, which is a significant result as it demonstrates the broad application range of Pt ALD, including applications involving temp.-sensitive materials.

A two-step process consisting of low temp. growth followed by rapid thermal annealing is demonstrated for Ru/(Pb,La)(Zr,Ti)O3 (PLZT)/Ru ferroelec. capacitors directly on Si. PLZT is a promising material for Gbit-scale ferroelec. memories, but its growth on Si proved challenging. The two-step process is designed to enable nucleation of perovskite phase PLZT while limiting diffusion which often leads to device failure. Minimization of stress and interdiffusion during film growth were necessary to optimize the remanent polarization. (Pb-4%La)(Zr0.3Ti0.7)O3 capacitors with remanent polarizations up to 17 μC/cm2 were grown on Ru/Si at 400° and 50 mtorr O2 using pulsed laser deposition. Direct high temp. growth (>600°) was not possible due to interface reactions, and film cracking was obsd. at low temps. as well as at high and low O pressures.

Oxygen diffusion through the grain boundaries of Pt films during the crystn. annealing of Pb(Zr,Ti)O3 (PZT) was investigated for the stacked structure of PZT/Pt/TiN. If the Pt film was sputtered on the TiN film by an in-vacuum process, then columnar (111)-oriented grains were grown with continuous grain boundaries normal to the substrate. On the other hand, a Pt film deposited on a TiN film exposed to air after the TiN deposition consisted of granular grains with a random orientation, because the Pt film was grown on the native oxide surface of the TiN film. The degree of oxygen diffusion in the Pt film deposited on the exposed TiN film was lower than that on the nonexposed TiN film after the PZT was crystd. at 650°C in O2. Differences in the grain boundary structure, such as the diffusion length, are considered to det. the oxygen diffusion rate.

Using at. layer deposition (ALD), we show that Pt nanoparticles can be deposited on the inner surfaces of carbon aerogels (CA). The resultant Pt-loaded materials exhibit high catalytic activity for the oxidn. of CO even at loading levels as low as ∼0.05 mg Pt/cm2. We observe a conversion efficiency of nearly 100% in the 150-250 °C temps. range, and the total conversion rate seems to be limited only by the thermal stability of the CA support in ambient oxygen. The ALD approach described here is universal in nature, and can be applied to the design of new catalytic materials for a variety of applications, including fuel cells, hydrogen storage, pollution control, green chem., and liq. fuel prodn.

This study describes an at. layer deposition (ALD) approach for the fabrication of Pt nanocatalysts supported on graphene oxide (GO) sheets and their electrocatalytic performance in electro-oxidn. of formic acid. The ALD process for forming the Pt at. layer involves two self-limiting reactions and, thus, induces the decoration of ALD-Pt on the edges of GO sheets with the presence of dangling bonds and oxygen functionalities. The resultant ALD-Pt catalyst on GO sheets offers better catalytic activity, CO tolerance, and long-term stability than those on com. carbon support. On the basis of the results, the ALD approach described here can be applied to the design of novel catalytic materials for a variety of energy-storage applications, for example, high-performance fuel cells.

Nanostructured metal films have been widely studied for their roles in sensing, catalysis, and energy storage. In this work, the synthesis of compositionally controlled and nanostructured Pt/Ir films by at. layer deposition (ALD) into porous anodized aluminum oxide templates is demonstrated. Templated ALD provides advantages over alternative synthesis techniques, including improved film uniformity and conformality as well as at.-scale control over morphol. and compn. Nanostructured Pt ALD films are demonstrated with morphol. control provided by the Pt precursor exposure time and the no. of ALD cycles. With these approaches, Pt films with enhanced surface areas, as characterized by roughness factors as large as 310, are reproducibly synthesized. Addnl., nanostructured PtIr alloy films of controlled compn. and morphol. are demonstrated by templated ALD, with compns. varying systematically from pure Pt to pure Ir. Lastly, the application of nanostructured Pt films to electrochem. sensing applications is demonstrated by the non-enzymic sensing of glucose.

Pt/SrTiO3 shows promise as a low temp. hydrocarbon combustion catalyst for automotive applications. In this study, SrTiO3 nanocuboid supports were synthesized using sol-pptn. coupled with hydrothermal synthesis, and platinum was deposited on the nanocuboids with 1, 3, and 5 cycles of at. layer deposition (ALD). The platinum particles have a highly uniform distribution both before and after reaction testing, and range from 1 to 5 nm in size, depending upon the no. of ALD cycles. These materials have a >50 °C lower light-off temp. for propane oxidn. than a conventional Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, turn over frequencies up to 3 orders of magnitude higher, and show improved resistance to deactivation. The increased activity is attributed to the stabilization of a Pt/PtO core/shell structure during operating conditions by the strong epitaxy between the Pt and the SrTiO3 support.

Lithog. defined microporous templates in conjunction with the at. layer deposition (ALD) technique enable remarkable control of complex novel nested nanotube structures. So far three-dimensional control of phys. process parameters has not been fully realized with high precision resoln., and requires optimization in order to achieve a wider range of potential applications. Furthermore, the combination of composite insulating oxide layers alternating with semiconducting layers and metals can provide various types of novel applications and eventually provide unique and advanced levels of multifunctional nanoscale devices. Semiconducting TiO2 nanotubes have potential applications in photovoltaic devices. The combination of nanostructured semiconducting materials with nested metal nanotubes has the potential to produce novel multifunctional vertically-ordered three-dimensional nanodevices. Platinum growth by ALD has been explored, covering the initial stages of the thin film nucleation process and the synthesis of high aspect ratio nanotube structures. The penetration depth of the Pt into porous templates having various pore sizes and aspect ratios has been investigated. Several multi-walled nested TiO2-Pt nanotubes in series have been successfully fabricated using microporous Si templates. These innovative nested nanostructures have the potential to produce novel multifunctional vertically-ordered three-dimensional nanodevices in photovoltaic and sensing technologies.

This study adopts a modified at. layer deposition (ALD) process to prep. size-controlled Pt nanoparticles on the surface of C black, showing superior catalytic activity toward EtOH oxidn. Two types of ALD precursors, (methylcyclopentadienyl) tri-Me Pt (MeCpPtMe3) and O (O2), were used to grow Pt deposits at 250°. For 30 ALD cycles, the pulse period of MeCpPtMe3 serves as a key factor in controlling the particle size and the wt. loading of Pt deposits. The Pt growth rates over the C support can be attributed to the surface coverage of Pt-O* sites, diffusion rate of MeCpPtMe3, and lateral interaction between each active site. Since the MeCpPtMe3 dose strongly affects the Pt particle size and the deposit d., the growth of ALD-Pt can be assumed as being diffusion-limited. Because of the surface-catalyzed reaction steps, the small-sized ALD-Pt catalysts offer better catalytic activity, CO tolerance, and long-term stability as compared with the large-sized ones. The modified ALD technique exhibits a great potential for tuning the Pt particle size and wt. loading onto the C support for fuel cell application.

Pt oxide and Pt thin films were grown by at. layer deposition (ALD) using Pt(acac)2 (acac = acetylacetonato) and ozone as precursors. Amorphous Pt oxide thin films were deposited at 120 and 130° while metallic Pt films were obtained at 140° and above. The sublimation temp. of Pt(acac)2 set the low temp. limit for oxide film deposition. The Pt oxide films were successfully deposited on Al2O3 and TiO2 adhesion layers, soda lime glass, and Si substrate with native oxide on top. Pt films were grown on Al2O3 adhesion layer. The Pt oxide had good adhesion to all tested surfaces, whereas metallic Pt films did not pass the common tape test. Resistivities of 50-60 nm thick Pt oxide films were 1.5-5 Ω cm at 130° and could be varied with both precursor pulse lengths. The resistivity of ∼110 nm thick metallic film deposited at 140° was ∼11 μΩ cm. The Pt films deposited at higher temps. suffered from deterioration of thickness uniformity. The Pt oxide films can be reduced in 5% H2 gas under reduced pressure at room temp. to porous Pt structures.

Mackus, Adriaan J. M.; Leick, Noemi; Baker, Layton; Kessels, Wilhelmus M. M.

Atomic layer deposition (ALD) processes of noble metals are gaining increasing interest for applications in catalysis and microelectronics. Platinum ALD from (methylcyclopentadienyl)trimethylplatinum (MeCpPtMe3) and O2 gas has been considered as a model system for noble metal ALD. However, many questions about the underlying reaction mechanisms remain. In this work, the insight into the Pt ALD reaction mechanisms is extended by considering the catalytic nature of the Pt film. It is evaluated which surface reactions are likely to take place during Pt ALD on the basis of surface science results on the interaction of the Pt surface with O2 and hydrocarbon species, combined with previously reported Pt ALD mechanistic studies. In analogy to the reactions of hydrocarbon species on catalytic Pt, it is proposed that, in addn. to combustion-like reactions, dehydrogenation of precursor ligands plays a role in the mechanism. The formation of CH4 during the MeCpPtMe3 exposure pulse is explained by hydrogenation of Me species by hydrogen atoms released from dehydrogenation reactions. The implications of the surface reactions on the self-limiting behavior, the growth rate, and the temp. dependence of the process are discussed. Moreover, this work demonstrates that surface science studies are of great use in obtaining more understanding of metal ALD processes.

The use of gas-phase electron-impact activation of metalorg. complexes to facilitate at. layer depositions (ALD) was tested for the case of (methylcyclopentadienyl)Pt(IV) tri-Me (MeCpPtMe3) on Si oxide films. Uptake enhancements of >1 order of magnitude were calcd. from XPS data. From the measured C:Pt ratios, the surface species mainly consist of MeCpPt moieties, likely because of the prevalent formation of [MeCpPtMex-nH]+ ions after gas-phase ionization (as detd. by mass spectrometry). Counterintuitively, more extensive adsorption was obsd. on thick SiO2 films than on the native thin SiO2 film that forms on Si(100) wafers, despite the former having virtually no surface OH groups. We demonstrate a method for growing metal nanoparticles (NPs) by at. layer deposition (ALD) with the ability to vary aerial d. and NP size using nucleation control. Self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) preadsorbed on the substrate serve as a template for subsequent growth of the NPs by ALD. Defects in the SAM resulting from incomplete formation time in soln. are shown to act as nucleation sites for Pt. The strategy is demonstrated exptl. using ALD of Pt from a metal org. Pt precursor and O2 counter reactant on silicon dioxide surfaces pretreated with octadecyltrichlorosilane SAMs. The aerial d. and mean diam. of the Pt NPs are controlled by changing the SAM dip time and the no. of ALD cycles. An isothermal nucleation model was developed in which several nucleation behaviors were considered in comparison with exptl. data. A model incorporating nucleation incubation provided the best fit to the data.

Cu was electroplated on a 10-nm-thick Ru film. Interestingly, the N could be incorporated into Ru at a higher reactant gas ratio of 0.86. The N-incorporated Ru film (≈20 at.% of N) formed a nanocryst. and non-columnar grain structure with the resistivity of ≈340 μΩ cm.

Pt thin films were grown by plasma-enhanced at. layer deposition (PEALD) using (methylcyclopentadienyl)trimethylPt (MeCpPtMe3) as precursor and resp. an O2, N2, and NH3 plasma as reactant. For each process the film thickness was found to be linearly dependent on the no. of reaction cycles. Satn. curves and temp. windows were defined and growth rates of 0.45 Å cycle-1, 0.30 Å cycle-1 and 0.40 Å cycle-1 were obtained for the O2, N2, and NH3 process resp. All the films were metallic Pt, cryst., uniform and closed, with low surface roughness and low impurity levels. At a pressure of 1 × 10-3 mbar, nucleation on SiO2 was remarkably faster with the NH3 and N2 processes than with the O2 process. In-situ OES and MS measurements showed a fundamental difference between the NH3 and N2 processes and the O2 process. Based on these measurements we propose a reaction mechanism for the N2 and NH3 PEALD processes where N2 will unstably adsorb on the substrate during the plasma pulse and be used during the subsequent precursor pulse to remove part of the precursor ligands.

The controllability of the nucleation behavior of Pt in atomic layer deposition (ALD) by surface pretreatments with H2O, H2S, and NH3 was investigated. The H2O pretreatment on SiO2 and TiO2 surfaces had little effect on the nucleation of Pt. The H2S pretreatment on the SiO2 and TiO2 surfaces significantly delayed the nucleation of Pt on them, while the NH3 pretreatment on the TiO2 surface led to fluent nucleation of Pt. In particular, a continuous Pt film was successfully formed even at an ultrathin thickness of approximately 2.2 nm by NH3 pretreatment. This work suggests that the pretreatment with H2S and NH3 is an efficient way to control the nucleation of Pt in ALD without the support of any reactive species, such as plasma or O3. Such a strategy enables the easy control of the size and distribution density of Pt nanoparticles for a wide range of applications.

The authors present an efficient scheme for calcg. the Kohn-Sham ground state of metallic systems using pseudopotentials and a plane-wave basis set. In the first part the application of Pulay's DIIS method (direct inversion in the iterative subspace) to the iterative diagonalization of large matrixes will be discussed. This approach is stable, reliable, and minimizes the no. of order Natoms3 operations. In the second part, we will discuss an efficient mixing scheme also based on Pulay's scheme. A special "metric" and a special "preconditioning" optimized for a plane-wave basis set will be introduced. Scaling of the method will be discussed in detail for non-self-consistent and self-consistent calcns. It will be shown that the no. of iterations required to obtain a specific precision is almost independent of the system size. Altogether an order Natoms2 scaling is found for systems contg. up to 1000 electrons. If we take into account that the no. of k points can be decreased linearly with the system size, the overall scaling can approach Natoms. They have implemented these algorithms within a powerful package called VASP (Vienna ab initio simulation package). The program and the techniques have been used successfully for a large no. of different systems (liq. and amorphous semiconductors, liq. simple and transition metals, metallic and semiconducting surfaces, phonons in simple metals, transition metals, and semiconductors) and turned out to be very reliable.

The formal relationship between ultrasoft (US) Vanderbilt-type pseudopotentials and Blochl's projector augmented wave (PAW) method is derived. The total energy functional for US pseudopotentials can be obtained by linearization of two terms in a slightly modified PAW total energy functional. The Hamilton operator, the forces, and the stress tensor are derived for this modified PAW functional. A simple way to implement the PAW method in existing plane-wave codes supporting US pseudopotentials is pointed out. In addn., crit. tests are presented to compare the accuracy and efficiency of the PAW and the US pseudopotential method with relaxed-core all-electron methods. These tests include small mols. (H2, H2O, Li2, N2, F2, BF3, SiF4) and several bulk systems (diamond, Si, V, Li, Ca, CaF2, Fe, Co, Ni). Particular attention is paid to the bulk properties and magnetic energies of Fe, Co, and Ni.

A simple method for computing accurate d.-dependent dispersion coeffs. is presented. Std. d. functional approxns. cannot accurately describe interactions between nonoverlapping densities. A simple remedy consists in correcting for the missing interactions a posteriori, adding an attractive energy term summed over all atom pairs. The d.-dependent energy correction, dDsC, presented herein, is constructed from dispersion coeffs. computed on the basis of a generalized gradient approxn. to Becke and Johnson's exchange-hole dipole moment formalism. DDsC also relies on an extended Tang and Toennies damping function accounting for charge-overlap effects. The comprehensive benchmarking on 341 diverse reaction energies divided into 18 illustrative test sets validates the robust performance and general accuracy of dDsC for describing various intra- and intermol. interactions. With a total MAD of 1.3 kcal mol-1, B97-dDsC slightly improves the results of M06-2X and B2PLYP-D3 (MAD = 1.4 kcal mol-1 for both) at a lower computational cost. The d. dependence of both the dispersion coeffs. and the damping function makes the approach esp. valuable for modeling redox reactions and charged species in general.

Reaction mechanisms in at. layer deposition (ALD) of ruthenium from bis(cyclopentadienyl)ruthenium (RuCp2) and oxygen were studied in situ with a quadrupole mass spectrometer (QMS) and a quartz crystal microbalance (QCM). In addn., QMS was used to study ALD of platinum from (methylcyclopentadienyl)trimethylplatinum (MeCpPtMe3) and oxygen. The QMS studies showed that the reaction byproducts H2O and CO2 were released during both the oxygen and the metal precursor pulses. Adsorbed oxygen layer on the metal surface thus oxidizes part of the ligands during the metal precursor pulse. The remaining ligand species become oxidized and a new layer of adsorbed oxygen forms on the surface during the following oxygen pulse. The QCM anal. of the ruthenium process showed a mass decrease during the RuCp2 pulse and a mass increase during the oxygen pulse, which further supports the proposed mechanism.

Many reported at. layer deposition (ALD) processes are carried out at elevated temps. (>150°), which can be problematic for temp.-sensitive substrates. Plasma-enhanced ALD routes may provide a soln., as the ALD temp. window can, in theory, be extended to lower deposition temps. due to the reactive nature of the plasma. As such, the plasma-enhanced ALD of Al2O3, TiO2, and Ta2O5 has been investigated at 25-400° using [Al(CH3)3], [Ti(OiPr)4], [Ti(CpMe)(OiPr)3], [TiCp*(OMe)3], and [Ta(NMe2)5] as precursors. An O2 plasma was employed as the oxygen source in each case. We have demonstrated metal oxide thin-film deposition at temps. as low as room temp. and compared the results with corresponding thermal ALD routes to the same materials. The compn. of the films was detd. by Rutherford backscattering spectroscopy. Anal. of the growth per cycle data and the metal atoms deposited per cycle revealed that the growth per cycle is strongly dependent on the film d. at low deposition temps. Comparison of these data for Al2O3 ALD processes in particular, showed that the no. of Al atoms deposited per cycle was consistently high down to room temp. for the plasma-enhanced process but dropped for the thermal process at substrate temps. lower than 250°.

Surface chemistry of atomic layer deposition: A case study for the trimethylaluminum/water process
Puurunen, Riikka L.
Journal of Applied Physics
(

),

(

121301/1-121301/52

)
A review. At. layer deposition (ALD), a chem. vapor deposition technique based on sequential self-terminating gas-solid reactions, has for about four decades been applied for manufg. conformal inorg. material layers with thickness down to the nanometer range. Despite the numerous successful applications of material growth by ALD, many physicochem. processes that control ALD growth are not yet sufficiently understood. To increase understanding of ALD processes, overviews are needed not only of the existing ALD processes and their applications, but also of the knowledge of the surface chem. of specific ALD processes. This work aims to start the overviews on specific ALD processes by reviewing the exptl. information available on the surface chem. of the trimethylaluminum/water process. This process is generally known as a rather ideal ALD process, and plenty of information is available on its surface chem. This in-depth summary of the surface chem. of one representative ALD process aims also to provide a view on the current status of understanding the surface chem. of ALD, in general. The review starts by describing the basic characteristics of ALD, discussing the history of ALD-including the question who made the first ALD expts.-and giving an overview of the two-reactant ALD processes investigated to date. Second, the basic concepts related to the surface chem. of ALD are described from a generic viewpoint applicable to all ALD processes based on compd. reactants. This description includes physicochem. requirements for self-terminating reactions, reaction kinetics, typical chemisorption mechanisms, factors causing satn., reasons for growth of less than a monolayer per cycle, effect of the temp. and no. of cycles on the growth per cycle (GPC), and the growth mode. A comparison is made of three models available for estg. the sterically allowed value of GPC in ALD. Third, the exptl. information on the surface chem. in the trimethylaluminum/water ALD process are reviewed using the concepts developed in the second part of this review. The results are reviewed critically, with an aim to combine the information obtained in different types of investigations, such as growth expts. on flat substrates and reaction chem. investigation on high-surface-area materials. Although the surface chem. of the trimethylaluminum/water ALD process is rather well understood, systematic investigations of the reaction kinetics and the growth mode on different substrates are still missing. The last part of the review is devoted to discussing issues which may hamper surface chem. investigations of ALD, such as problematic historical assumptions, nonstandard terminol., and the effect of exptl. conditions on the surface chem. of ALD. I hope that this review can help the newcomer get acquainted with the exciting and challenging field of surface chem. of ALD and can serve as a useful guide for the specialist towards the fifth decade of ALD research.

We report the catalyzed at. layer deposition (ALD) of silicon oxide using Si2Cl6, H2O, and various alkylamines. The d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. using the periodic slab model of the SiO2 surface were performed for the selection of alternative Lewis base catalysts with high catalytic activities. During the first half-reaction, the catalysts with less steric hindrance such as pyridine would be more effective than bulky alkylamines despite lower nucleophilicity. On the other hand, during the second half-reaction, the catalysts with a high nucleophilicity such as triethylamine (Et3N) would be more efficient because the steric hindrance is less crit. The in situ process monitoring shows that the calcd. at. charge is a good indicator for expecting the catalyst activity in the ALD reaction. The use of Et3N in the second half-reaction was essential to improving the growth rate as well as the step coverage of the film because the Et3N-catalyzed process deposited a SiO2 film with a step coverage of 98% that is better than 93% of the pyridine-catalyzed process. The adsorption of pyridine, ammonia (NH3), or trimethylamine (Me3N) salts was more favorable than that of Et3N, n-Pr3N, or iPr3N salts. Therefore, Et3N was expected to incorporate less amine salts in the film as compared to pyridine, and the compositional analyses confirmed that the concns. of Cl and N by the Et3N-catalyzed process were significantly lower than those by the pyridine-catalyzed process.

The kinetics of the thermal chem. of methylcyclopentadienyl manganese tricarbonyl on copper surfaces was followed by IR absorption spectroscopy anal. of the gas surrounding the substrate. Dissociative adsorption of the MeCpMn(CO)3 precursor was seen at low temps., below 400 K, and was detd. to occur via the initial loss of a single carbon monoxide ligand. Full decarbonylation was obsd. starting at a surface temp. of approx. 510 K, and full decompn. of the Mn precursor was seen to be complete by 540 K. All these transitions were detd. to occur at temps. at least 100 K lower than those reported on silicon oxide surfaces. Comparison with ref. spectra afforded the identification of the main hydrocarbon product as a mixt. of methylcyclopentadiene isomers. Isothermal measurements of MeCpMn(CO)3 partial pressure vs. reaction time highlighted a deviation from first-order kinetics, an effect assocd. with changes in surface reactivity. A self-limiting regime typical of at. layer deposition processes was identified between 475 and 525 K by the incomplete conversion of the precursor, which displayed similar reaction rate and reached the same asymptotic partial pressure at all temps. within that temp. bracket. Higher surface temps. promoted total precursor consumption, at a rate that increased with increasing surface temp.; an apparent activation energy of approx. 40 kJ/mol was estd. in that high-temp. regime. The resulting chem.-vapor deposited multilayers were identified by XPS to consist of MnO.

Agglomeration is a crit. issue for depositing copper (Cu) thin films, and therefore, the deposition should be preferably performed <100°. This work explores an at. layer deposition (ALD) process for copper thin films deposited at temp. ≥50°. The process employs copper(I)-N,N'-diisopropylacetamidinate precursor and H2 plasma, which are both highly reactive at low temp. The deposition process <100° follows an ideal self-limiting ALD fashion with a satd. growth rate of 0.071 nm/cycle. Benefitting from the low process temp., the agglomeration of Cu thin films is largely suppressed, and the Cu films deposited at 50° are pure, continuous, smooth, and highly conformal, with the resistivity comparable to PVD Cu films. In-situ reaction mechanism studies by using quartz crystal microbalance and optical emission spectroscopy are followed, and the results confirm the high reactivity of the Cu amidinate precursor at low temp. This is the 1st successful implementation of metal amidinate precursors for low-temp. (∼50°) ALD process. The strategy of using metal amidinate precursors in combination with highly reactive H2 plasma is believed to be extendable for the depositions of other pure metals at low temp.

The lowering of the work function (Φ) can lead to a better field emission (FE) behavior at lower threshold fields. We report on enhanced FE from randomly oriented and faceted Au-capped ZnO hetero-nanostructures (HNs) having more oxygen defects. Large-area arrays of non-aligned, faceted Au-capped ZnO HNs, such as nanowires (NWs) and triangular nanoflakes (TNFs) are grown using the chem. vapor deposition (CVD) method. Enhanced FE properties from the TNF sample resulted in a turn-on field as low as 0.52 V μm-1 at a c.d. of 0.1 mA cm-2 and a field enhancement factor (β) as high as ≈5.16 × 105. Under similar exptl. conditions, drawing the same c.d. from an NW specimen needs a higher turn-on field (0.86 V μm-1) and to exhibit nearly four times less field enhancement factor compared to the TNFs samples. XPS and photoluminescence (PL) measurements confirm the presence of more oxygen defects in the TNF samples compared to the NW samples. Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) measurements show the av. local work function to be 4.70 ± 0.1 eV for the TNF sample, which is ≈0.34 eV lower than the NW sample. Using d. functional theory (DFT) calcns., the estd. Φ values are found to be 4.98 eV for ZnO(0001), 4.17 eV for Au(001)/ZnO(0001) and 3.91 eV for Au(001)/Ovac-ZnO(0001) surfaces. The DFT results are qual. in agreement with our exptl. results. The presence of Au nanostructures on top of O-deficient and sharp-tipped TNFs results in enhanced FE performance following their reduced tunneling barrier via pinning of effective Φ.

Phase engineering of seamless heterophase homojunctions with co-existing 3R and 2H phases in WS2 monolayers
Kumar, Pawan; Verma, Navneet Chandra; Goyal, Natasha; Biswas, Jayeeta; Lodha, Saurabh; Nandi, Chayan K.; Balakrishnan, Viswanath
Nanoscale
(
2018
),
10
(
7
),
3320-3330
CODEN:
NANOHL
; ISSN:
2040-3372
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
Self-organized semiconductor-semiconductor heterostructures (3R-2H) that coexist in atomically thin 2D monolayers forming homojunctions are of great importance for next-generation nanoelectronics and optoelectronics applications. Herein, we investigated the defect controlled growth of heterogeneous electronic structure within a single domain of monolayer WS2 to enable in-plane homojunctions consisting of alternate 2H semiconducting and 3R semiconducting phases of WS2. X-ray photoelectron, Raman, and photoluminescence spectroscopy along with fluorescence and Kelvin probe force microscopy imaging confirm the formation of homojunctions, enabling a direct correlation between chem. heterogeneity and electronic heterostructure in the atomically thin WS2 monolayer. Quant. anal. of phase fractions shows 59% stable 2H phase and 41% metastable 3R phase estd. over WS2 flakes of different sizes. Time-resolved fluorescence lifetime imaging confirms distinct contrast between 2H and 3R phases with two distinct lifetimes of 3.2 ns and 1.1 ns, resp. Kelvin probe force microscopy imaging revealed an abrupt change in the contact p.d. with a depletion width of ∼2.5 μm, capturing a difference in work function of ∼40 meV across the homojunction. Further, the thermal stability of coexisting phases and their temp. dependent optical behavior show a distinct difference among 2H and 3R phases. The investigated aspects of the controlled in plane growth of coexisting phases with seamless homojunctions, their properties, and their thermal stability will enable the development of nanoscale devices that are free from issues of lattice mismatch and grain boundaries.

Sensing the Charge State of Single Gold Nanoparticles via Work Function Measurements
Zhang, Yingjie; Pluchery, Olivier; Caillard, Louis; Lamic-Humblot, Anne-Felicie; Casale, Sandra; Chabal, Yves J.; Salmeron, Miquel
Nano Letters
(
2015

(
1
),
51-55
CODEN:

; ISSN:
1530-6984
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
Electrostatic interactions at the nanoscale can lead to novel properties and functionalities that bulk materials and devices do not have. Here the authors used Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) to study the work function (WF) of Au nanoparticles (NPs) deposited on a Si wafer covered by a monolayer of alkyl chains, which provide a tunnel junction. The WF of Au NPs is size-dependent and deviates strongly from that of the bulk Au. The authors attribute the WF change to the charging of the NPs, which is a consequence of the difference in WF between Au and the substrate. For an NP with 10 nm diam. charged with ∼5 electrons, the WF is only ∼3.6 eV. A classical electrostatic model is derived that explains the observations in a quant. way. Also the WF and charge state of Au NPs are influenced by chem. changes of the underlying substrate. Therefore, Au NPs could be used for chem. and biol. sensing, whose environmentally sensitive charge state can be read out by work function measurements.

Platinum and platinum oxide films were deposited by remote plasma at. layer deposition (ALD) from the combination of (methylcyclopentadienyl)trimethylplatinum (MeCpPtMe3) precursor and O2 plasma. A short O2 plasma exposure (0.5 s) resulted in low resistivity (15 μΩ/cm), high d. (21 g/cm3), cubic Pt films, whereas a longer O2 plasma exposure (5 s) resulted in semiconductive PtO2 films. In situ spectroscopic ellipsometry studies revealed no significant nucleation delay, different from the thermal ALD process with O2 gas which was used as a benchmark. A broad temp. window (100-300°) for remote plasma ALD of Pt and PtO2 was demonstrated.

Plasma-assisted at. layer deposition (ALD) processes were developed for the deposition of platinum films at room temp. High-quality, virtually pure films with a resistivity of 18-24 μΩ cm were obtained for processes consisting of MeCpPtMe3 dosing, O2 plasma exposure, and H2 gas or H2 plasma exposure. The H2 pulses were used to reduce the PtOx that is otherwise deposited at low substrate temps. It is shown that the processes enable the deposition of Pt on polymer, textile, and paper substrates, which is a significant result as it demonstrates the broad application range of Pt ALD, including applications involving temp.-sensitive materials.

A two-step process consisting of low temp. growth followed by rapid thermal annealing is demonstrated for Ru/(Pb,La)(Zr,Ti)O3 (PLZT)/Ru ferroelec. capacitors directly on Si. PLZT is a promising material for Gbit-scale ferroelec. memories, but its growth on Si proved challenging. The two-step process is designed to enable nucleation of perovskite phase PLZT while limiting diffusion which often leads to device failure. Minimization of stress and interdiffusion during film growth were necessary to optimize the remanent polarization. (Pb-4%La)(Zr0.3Ti0.7)O3 capacitors with remanent polarizations up to 17 μC/cm2 were grown on Ru/Si at 400° and 50 mtorr O2 using pulsed laser deposition. Direct high temp. growth (>600°) was not possible due to interface reactions, and film cracking was obsd. at low temps. as well as at high and low O pressures.

Oxygen diffusion through the grain boundaries of Pt films during the crystn. annealing of Pb(Zr,Ti)O3 (PZT) was investigated for the stacked structure of PZT/Pt/TiN. If the Pt film was sputtered on the TiN film by an in-vacuum process, then columnar (111)-oriented grains were grown with continuous grain boundaries normal to the substrate. On the other hand, a Pt film deposited on a TiN film exposed to air after the TiN deposition consisted of granular grains with a random orientation, because the Pt film was grown on the native oxide surface of the TiN film. The degree of oxygen diffusion in the Pt film deposited on the exposed TiN film was lower than that on the nonexposed TiN film after the PZT was crystd. at 650°C in O2. Differences in the grain boundary structure, such as the diffusion length, are considered to det. the oxygen diffusion rate.

Using at. layer deposition (ALD), we show that Pt nanoparticles can be deposited on the inner surfaces of carbon aerogels (CA). The resultant Pt-loaded materials exhibit high catalytic activity for the oxidn. of CO even at loading levels as low as ∼0.05 mg Pt/cm2. We observe a conversion efficiency of nearly 100% in the 150-250 °C temps. range, and the total conversion rate seems to be limited only by the thermal stability of the CA support in ambient oxygen. The ALD approach described here is universal in nature, and can be applied to the design of new catalytic materials for a variety of applications, including fuel cells, hydrogen storage, pollution control, green chem., and liq. fuel prodn.

This study describes an at. layer deposition (ALD) approach for the fabrication of Pt nanocatalysts supported on graphene oxide (GO) sheets and their electrocatalytic performance in electro-oxidn. of formic acid. The ALD process for forming the Pt at. layer involves two self-limiting reactions and, thus, induces the decoration of ALD-Pt on the edges of GO sheets with the presence of dangling bonds and oxygen functionalities. The resultant ALD-Pt catalyst on GO sheets offers better catalytic activity, CO tolerance, and long-term stability than those on com. carbon support. On the basis of the results, the ALD approach described here can be applied to the design of novel catalytic materials for a variety of energy-storage applications, for example, high-performance fuel cells.

Nanostructured metal films have been widely studied for their roles in sensing, catalysis, and energy storage. In this work, the synthesis of compositionally controlled and nanostructured Pt/Ir films by at. layer deposition (ALD) into porous anodized aluminum oxide templates is demonstrated. Templated ALD provides advantages over alternative synthesis techniques, including improved film uniformity and conformality as well as at.-scale control over morphol. and compn. Nanostructured Pt ALD films are demonstrated with morphol. control provided by the Pt precursor exposure time and the no. of ALD cycles. With these approaches, Pt films with enhanced surface areas, as characterized by roughness factors as large as 310, are reproducibly synthesized. Addnl., nanostructured PtIr alloy films of controlled compn. and morphol. are demonstrated by templated ALD, with compns. varying systematically from pure Pt to pure Ir. Lastly, the application of nanostructured Pt films to electrochem. sensing applications is demonstrated by the non-enzymic sensing of glucose.

Pt/SrTiO3 shows promise as a low temp. hydrocarbon combustion catalyst for automotive applications. In this study, SrTiO3 nanocuboid supports were synthesized using sol-pptn. coupled with hydrothermal synthesis, and platinum was deposited on the nanocuboids with 1, 3, and 5 cycles of at. layer deposition (ALD). The platinum particles have a highly uniform distribution both before and after reaction testing, and range from 1 to 5 nm in size, depending upon the no. of ALD cycles. These materials have a >50 °C lower light-off temp. for propane oxidn. than a conventional Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, turn over frequencies up to 3 orders of magnitude higher, and show improved resistance to deactivation. The increased activity is attributed to the stabilization of a Pt/PtO core/shell structure during operating conditions by the strong epitaxy between the Pt and the SrTiO3 support.

We observe a conversion efficiency of nearly 100% in the 150-250 °C temps. range, and the total conversion rate seems to be limited only by the thermal stability of the CA support in ambient oxygen. Lithog. defined microporous templates in conjunction with the at. layer deposition (ALD) technique enable remarkable control of complex novel nested nanotube structures. So far three-dimensional control of phys. process parameters has not been fully realized with high precision resoln., and requires optimization in order to achieve a wider range of potential applications. Furthermore, the combination of composite insulating oxide layers alternating with semiconducting layers and metals can provide various types of novel applications and eventually provide unique and advanced levels of multifunctional nanoscale devices. Semiconducting TiO2 nanotubes have potential applications in photovoltaic devices. The combination of nanostructured semiconducting materials with nested metal nanotubes has the potential to produce novel multifunctional vertically-ordered three-dimensional nanodevices. Platinum growth by ALD has been explored, covering the initial stages of the thin film nucleation process and the synthesis of high aspect ratio nanotube structures. The penetration depth of the Pt into porous templates having various pore sizes and aspect ratios has been investigated. Several multi-walled nested TiO2-Pt nanotubes in series have been successfully fabricated using microporous Si templates. These innovative nested nanostructures have the potential to produce novel multifunctional vertically-ordered three-dimensional nanodevices in photovoltaic and sensing technologies.

This study adopts a modified at. layer deposition (ALD) process to prep. size-controlled Pt nanoparticles on the surface of C black, showing superior catalytic activity toward EtOH oxidn. Two types of ALD precursors, (methylcyclopentadienyl) tri-Me Pt (MeCpPtMe3) and O (O2), were used to grow Pt deposits at 250°. For 30 ALD cycles, the pulse period of MeCpPtMe3 serves as a key factor in controlling the particle size and the wt. loading of Pt deposits. The Pt growth rates over the C support can be attributed to the surface coverage of Pt-O* sites, diffusion rate of MeCpPtMe3, and lateral interaction between each active site. Since the MeCpPtMe3 dose strongly affects the Pt particle size and the deposit d., the growth of ALD-Pt can be assumed as being diffusion-limited. Because of the surface-catalyzed reaction steps, the small-sized ALD-Pt catalysts offer better catalytic activity, CO tolerance, and long-term stability as compared with the large-sized ones. The modified ALD technique exhibits a great potential for tuning the Pt particle size and wt. loading onto the C support for fuel cell application.

Pt oxide and Pt thin films were grown by at. layer deposition (ALD) using Pt(acac)2 (acac = acetylacetonato) and ozone as precursors. Amorphous Pt oxide thin films were deposited at 120 and 130° while metallic Pt films were obtained at 140° and above. The sublimation temp. of Pt(acac)2 set the low temp. limit for oxide film deposition. The Pt oxide films were successfully deposited on Al2O3 and TiO2 adhesion layers, soda lime glass, and Si substrate with native oxide on top. Pt films were grown on Al2O3 adhesion layer. The Pt oxide had good adhesion to all tested surfaces, whereas metallic Pt films did not pass the common tape test. Resistivities of 50-60 nm thick Pt oxide films were 1.5-5 Ω cm at 130° and could be varied with both precursor pulse lengths. The resistivity of ∼110 nm thick metallic film deposited at 140° was ∼11 μΩ cm. The Pt films deposited at higher temps. suffered from deterioration of thickness uniformity. The Pt oxide films can be reduced in 5% H2 gas under reduced pressure at room temp. to porous Pt structures.

Atomic layer deposition (ALD) processes of noble metals are gaining increasing interest for applications in catalysis and microelectronics. Platinum ALD from (methylcyclopentadienyl)trimethylplatinum (MeCpPtMe3) and O2 gas has been considered as a model system for noble metal ALD. However, many questions about the underlying reaction mechanisms remain. In this work, the insight into the Pt ALD reaction mechanisms is extended by considering the catalytic nature of the Pt film. It is evaluated which surface reactions are likely to take place during Pt ALD on the basis of surface science results on the interaction of the Pt surface with O2 and hydrocarbon species, combined with previously reported Pt ALD mechanistic studies. In analogy to the reactions of hydrocarbon species on catalytic Pt, it is proposed that, in addn. to combustion-like reactions, dehydrogenation of precursor ligands plays a role in the mechanism. The formation of CH4 during the MeCpPtMe3 exposure pulse is explained by hydrogenation of Me species by hydrogen atoms released from dehydrogenation reactions. The implications of the surface reactions on the self-limiting behavior, the growth rate, and the temp. dependence of the process are discussed. Moreover, this work demonstrates that surface science studies are of great use in obtaining more understanding of metal ALD processes.

Deposition was possible using H2 mols. without a plasma by increasing the chamber pressure to above 10 Torr. Specifically, high-quality Ru films with a low resistivity of ∼40 μΩ cm and few amt. of oxygen (∼1.2 at. %) were obtained under a chamber pressure of 300 Torr though the oxygen was contained in the precursor. Under the optimized conditions, self-limited film growth with regard to the precursor and reactant pulsing times was confirmed under elevated chamber pressures. The ALD-Ru process proposed in this study showed one of the highest growth rates of 0.12 nm/cycle on a thermally grown SiO2 substrate, as well as a very low no. of incubation cycles (approx. 12 cycles). Cross-sectional view transmission electron microscopy showed that no interfacial oxide had formed during the deposition of the ALD-Ru films on a W surface using H2 mols., whereas ∼7 nm thick interfacial oxide was formed when O2 mols. were used as a reactant. The step coverage of the ALD-Ru film onto very small-sized trenches (aspect ratio: ∼4.5 and the top opening size of 25 nm) and holes (aspect ratio: ∼40 and top opening size of 40 nm) was excellent (∼100%). Pt thin films were grown by plasma-enhanced at. layer deposition (PEALD) using (methylcyclopentadienyl)trimethylPt (MeCpPtMe3) as precursor and resp. an O2, N2, and NH3 plasma as reactant. For each process the film thickness was found to be linearly dependent on the no. of reaction cycles. Satn. curves and temp. windows were defined and growth rates of 0.45 Å cycle-1, 0.30 Å cycle-1 and 0.40 Å cycle-1 were obtained for the O2, N2, and NH3 process resp. All the films were metallic Pt, cryst., uniform and closed, with low surface roughness and low impurity levels. At a pressure of 1 × 10-3 mbar, nucleation on SiO2 was remarkably faster with the NH3 and N2 processes than with the O2 process. In-situ OES and MS measurements showed a fundamental difference between the NH3 and N2 processes and the O2 process. Based on these measurements we propose a reaction mechanism for the N2 and NH3 PEALD processes where N2 will unstably adsorb on the substrate during the plasma pulse and be used during the subsequent precursor pulse to remove part of the precursor ligands.

The controllability of the nucleation behavior of Pt in atomic layer deposition (ALD) by surface pretreatments with H2O, H2S, and NH3 was investigated. The H2O pretreatment on SiO2 and TiO2 surfaces had little effect on the nucleation of Pt. The H2S pretreatment on the SiO2 and TiO2 surfaces significantly delayed the nucleation of Pt on them, while the NH3 pretreatment on the TiO2 surface led to fluent nucleation of Pt. In particular, a continuous Pt film was successfully formed even at an ultrathin thickness of approximately 2.2 nm by NH3 pretreatment. This work suggests that the pretreatment with H2S and NH3 is an efficient way to control the nucleation of Pt in ALD without the support of any reactive species, such as plasma or O3. Such a strategy enables the easy control of the size and distribution density of Pt nanoparticles for a wide range of applications.

The authors present an efficient scheme for calcg. the Kohn-Sham ground state of metallic systems using pseudopotentials and a plane-wave basis set. In the first part the application of Pulay's DIIS method (direct inversion in the iterative subspace) to the iterative diagonalization of large matrixes will be discussed. This approach is stable, reliable, and minimizes the no. of order Natoms3 operations. In the second part, we will discuss an efficient mixing scheme also based on Pulay's scheme. A special "metric" and a special "preconditioning" optimized for a plane-wave basis set will be introduced. Scaling of the method will be discussed in detail for non-self-consistent and self-consistent calcns. It will be shown that the no. of iterations required to obtain a specific precision is almost independent of the system size. Altogether an order Natoms2 scaling is found for systems contg. up to 1000 electrons. If we take into account that the no. of k points can be decreased linearly with the system size, the overall scaling can approach Natoms. They have implemented these algorithms within a powerful package called VASP (Vienna ab initio simulation package). The program and the techniques have been used successfully for a large no. of different systems (liq. and amorphous semiconductors, liq. simple and transition metals, metallic and semiconducting surfaces, phonons in simple metals, transition metals, and semiconductors) and turned out to be very reliable.

The formal relationship between ultrasoft (US) Vanderbilt-type pseudopotentials and Blochl's projector augmented wave (PAW) method is derived. The total energy functional for US pseudopotentials can be obtained by linearization of two terms in a slightly modified PAW total energy functional. The Hamilton operator, the forces, and the stress tensor are derived for this modified PAW functional. A simple way to implement the PAW method in existing plane-wave codes supporting US pseudopotentials is pointed out. In addn., crit. tests are presented to compare the accuracy and efficiency of the PAW and the US pseudopotential method with relaxed-core all-electron methods. These tests include small mols. (H2, H2O, Li2, N2, F2, BF3, SiF4) and several bulk systems (diamond, Si, V, Li, Ca, CaF2, Fe, Co, Ni). Particular attention is paid to the bulk properties and magnetic energies of Fe, Co, and Ni.

Std. d. functional approxns. cannot accurately describe interactions between nonoverlapping densities. A simple remedy consists in correcting for the missing interactions a posteriori, adding an attractive energy term summed over all atom pairs. The d.-dependent energy correction, dDsC, presented herein, is constructed from dispersion coeffs. computed on the basis of a generalized gradient approxn. to Becke and Johnson's exchange-hole dipole moment formalism. DDsC also relies on an extended Tang and Toennies damping function accounting for charge-overlap effects. The comprehensive benchmarking on 341 diverse reaction energies divided into 18 illustrative test sets validates the robust performance and general accuracy of dDsC for describing various intra- and intermol. interactions. With a total MAD of 1.3 kcal mol-1, B97-dDsC slightly improves the results of M06-2X and B2PLYP-D3 (MAD = 1.4 kcal mol-1 for both) at a lower computational cost. The d. dependence of both the dispersion coeffs. and the damping function makes the approach esp. valuable for modeling redox reactions and charged species in general.
